values.title: libprotobuf complains after translation / rotation when using JointControlWidget

content.raw:
I'm using the dev branch with the Joint Control Widget. If I translate or rotate a model, I get complaints from libprotobuf:

libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/message_lite.cc:123] Can't parse message of type "gazebo.msgs.Model" because it is missing required fields: name

While I have the mouse button pressed and am translating or rotating, the model information shows up in the Joint Control Widget. After releasing the click, the Joint Control Widget "loses focus" in that all the model information is gone. That's also when the complaint occurs.

values.title: Objects in contact may not update when new objects added to world

content.raw:
It's easiest to see with spheres, but it also happens with boxes and cylinders. In an empty world, if you add multiple spheres to the same snap location on the grid, they will stack on top of each other (a bit unrealistically). Then if you insert another sphere that partially overlaps the bottom sphere, the spheres on the ground will snap apart, so that the upper spheres go from being improbably balanced to floating unsupported (see screenshots).

If you right click and delete one of the spheres on the ground, everything wakes up and falls (like Wile E Coyote looking down).

I'm guessing that the upper spheres are auto-disabled and should be re-enabled when something comes in contact with the support sphere on the ground.
content.html:
It's easiest to see with spheres, but it also happens with boxes and cylinders. In an empty world, if you add multiple spheres to the same snap location on the grid, they will stack on top of each other (a bit unrealistically). Then if you insert another sphere that partially overlaps the bottom sphere, the spheres on the ground will snap apart, so that the upper spheres go from being improbably balanced to floating unsupported (see screenshots).

If you right click and delete one of the spheres on the ground, everything wakes up and falls (like Wile E Coyote looking down).

I'm guessing that the upper spheres are auto-disabled and should be re-enabled when something comes in contact with the support sphere on the ground.

values.title: Race condition in time reset for sensors

content.raw:
Sensors may not be successfully reset by a world_control message. There is a race condition between the Sensor::OnControl and World::OnControl functions since they are in different threads. If Sensor::OnControl executes first, then each sensor's lastUpdateTime will be reset to 0. However, a Sensor::Update may run before World::OnControl executes, which may increase the value of lastUpdateTime to the current sim time.

Basically, the sensors shouldn't be reset until the World has been reset, and these OnControl callbacks don't guarantee that.
content.html:
Sensors may not be successfully reset by a world_control message. There is a race condition between the Sensor::OnControl and World::OnControl functions since they are in different threads. If Sensor::OnControl executes first, then each sensor's lastUpdateTime will be reset to 0. However, a Sensor::Update may run before World::OnControl executes, which may increase the value of lastUpdateTime to the current sim time.

Basically, the sensors shouldn't be reset until the World has been reset, and these OnControl callbacks don't guarantee that.

values.title: Bug when reading common dae for collision and texture

content.raw:
This simple SDF uses one file for both the collison and visual elements:



```
#!xml
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<gazebo version='1.2'>
<model name="diy_box">
<static>true</static>
<link name='chassis'>
      <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
      <collision name='collision'>
        <geometry>
	    <mesh>
	     <uri>model://diy_box/meshes/diy_box.dae</uri>
	    </mesh>
        </geometry>
      </collision>
<visual name='visual'>
  <geometry>
    <mesh>
     <uri>model://diy_box/meshes/diy_box.dae</uri>
    </mesh>
  </geometry>
</visual>
</link>  
</model>
</gazebo>
```

Gazebo creates the collision element properly and in the Gazebo viewer correctly renderers the image BUT simulated camera images don't render the visual element. Instead its replaced by a black and yellow replacement texture.

I think that the file mustn't be being properly read because the following workaround works, using this SDF file:

```
#!xml
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<gazebo version='1.2'>
<model name="diy_box">
<static>true</static>
<link name='chassis'>
      <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
      <collision name='collision'>
        <geometry>
	    <mesh>
	     <uri>model://diy_box/meshes/diy_box.dae</uri>
	    </mesh>
        </geometry>
      </collision>
<visual name='visual'>
  <geometry>
    <mesh>
     <uri>model://diy_box/meshes/diy_box_copied_file.dae</uri>
    </mesh>
  </geometry>
</visual>
</link>  
</model>
</gazebo>
```

... where the diy_box_copied_file.dae is just a copy of the original file.

I'd imagine this is a trivial bug in whatever reads these files.

This simple SDF uses one file for both the collison and visual elements:

<?xml version='1.0'?>

      <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
      <collision name='collision'>
        <geometry>

         <uri>model://diy_box/meshes/diy_box.dae</uri>

<?xml version='1.0'?>
<gazebo version='1.2'>

values.title: Contact sensor refactor

content.raw:
## From Thomas Koletschka, in reference to clearing the contact map in ContactSensor::UpdateImpl.

I'm not sure whether the approach of clearing the contacts map at every time step works out well in the long run and it might actually introduce new bugs:
1) The public interface for getting information about contacts will fail most of the time, unless you're lucky and the function call gets through between the calls to OnContact() and UpdateImpl(). The functions GetCollision* and GetContacts make use of the contacts map which is empty after clearing it at the end of UpdateImpl so all the calls will result in "Contact Sensor [...] has no collision [...]" errors as the contacts map has a high chance of being empty even though a contact exists.

2) It certainly doesn't matter when you only have a few contact sensors but for example the iRobot hands have about 102 contact sensors each which results in hundreds of constructor and destructor calls every update while manipulating with both hands, which might affect performance a little I think.

I'm not sure what the best way around this would be but as (1) indicates clearing the contacts map probably does not go well unless you remove the public interface (the ros fuerte bumper plugin used it to get all the contacts) and only use the messages published by UpdateImpl. A callback indicating the loss of contact would probably allow for the most unproblematic solution but I don't know whether ODE allows for that.

## Other Notes

As Thomas mentions there is potentially many constructor and destructors for contact generation. A more streamlined approach is necessary.
content.html:
From Thomas Koletschka, in reference to clearing the contact map in ContactSensor::UpdateImpl.

I'm not sure whether the approach of clearing the contacts map at every time step works out well in the long run and it might actually introduce new bugs: 1) The public interface for getting information about contacts will fail most of the time, unless you're lucky and the function call gets through between the calls to OnContact() and UpdateImpl(). The functions GetCollision* and GetContacts make use of the contacts map which is empty after clearing it at the end of UpdateImpl so all the calls will result in "Contact Sensor [...] has no collision [...]" errors as the contacts map has a high chance of being empty even though a contact exists.

2) It certainly doesn't matter when you only have a few contact sensors but for example the iRobot hands have about 102 contact sensors each which results in hundreds of constructor and destructor calls every update while manipulating with both hands, which might affect performance a little I think.

I'm not sure what the best way around this would be but as (1) indicates clearing the contacts map probably does not go well unless you remove the public interface (the ros fuerte bumper plugin used it to get all the contacts) and only use the messages published by UpdateImpl. A callback indicating the loss of contact would probably allow for the most unproblematic solution but I don't know whether ODE allows for that.

Other Notes

As Thomas mentions there is potentially many constructor and destructors for contact generation. A more streamlined approach is necessary.

roscore
gazebo mit_driving_task_wheeled_robot_terrain.world
rosrun keyboard_teleop keyboard_teleop

Could you give me some feed back on this or do you have a well tested terrain map and robot model combo that I could build off of instead?

values.title: Missing build dependency somewhere in message generation

content.raw:
When switching branches, a compile error like this is common:

    /home/gerkey/code/drc/gazebo/gazebo/msgs/msgs.cc: In function ‘gazebo::msgs::GUI gazebo::msgs::GUIFromSDF(sdf::ElementPtr)’:
    /home/gerkey/code/drc/gazebo/gazebo/msgs/msgs.cc:302:29: error: ‘class gazebo::msgs::GUICamera’ has no member named ‘mutable_origin’
    make[2]: *** [gazebo/msgs/CMakeFiles/gazebo_msgs.dir/msgs.cc.o] Error 1
    make[1]: *** [gazebo/msgs/CMakeFiles/gazebo_msgs.dir/all] Error 2
    make: *** [all] Error 2

The problem seems to be that a `.proto` file was changed, but the protobuf compiler was not re-run.  Removing the generated message headers (`build/gazebo/msgs`) fixes it.

There's likely something missing in the dependency structure for message-generation.
content.html:
When switching branches, a compile error like this is common:

/home/gerkey/code/drc/gazebo/gazebo/msgs/msgs.cc: In function ‘gazebo::msgs::GUI gazebo::msgs::GUIFromSDF(sdf::ElementPtr)’:
/home/gerkey/code/drc/gazebo/gazebo/msgs/msgs.cc:302:29: error: ‘class gazebo::msgs::GUICamera’ has no member named ‘mutable_origin’
make[2]: *** [gazebo/msgs/CMakeFiles/gazebo_msgs.dir/msgs.cc.o] Error 1
make[1]: *** [gazebo/msgs/CMakeFiles/gazebo_msgs.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [all] Error 2

The problem seems to be that a .proto file was changed, but the protobuf compiler was not re-run. Removing the generated message headers (build/gazebo/msgs) fixes it.

There's likely something missing in the dependency structure for message-generation.

values.title: Seg-fault by gzclient while rendering DynamicLines when messing with lights

content.raw:
I don't have a robust procedure for this, but it happens if I mess around with the lights enough. I load an empty world, add one light of each type, then delete them, then go to add more lights, move them around, etc. Eventually gzclient will seg-fault and each time it's in [gazebo::rendering::Visual::Update:447 where it's rendering DynamicLines](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/3dd9883f24dbfb425e779e7a3ee77a09105a17b1/gazebo/rendering/Visual.cc?at=gazebo_1.3#cl-447).

I was experiencing this problem in the default branch, but then I tried it in gazebo_1.3 after Nate said it had been fixed. It was pretty easy to cause the problem in default, while it took longer in gazebo_1.3, but I was still able to reproduce it two times.

I've attached two separate backtraces from gdb.

If you're not using gdb, gzclient just dies silently with the server still running.

values.title: Relative pose of collisions may be incorrect until Reset World

content.raw:
In the attached world file `spheres.xml`, there is a ground plane, and a model containing two unconnected spheres. `sphere1` has it's c.g., visual, and collision at the origin of the model, while `sphere10` has identical pose offsets for c.g., visual, and collision.

When starting gazebo with this world, `sphere1` will fall and land on the ground as expected, while `sphere10` appears to sink through the ground and swing like a pendulum, popping up periodically.

After performing a World Reset, both spheres behave properly.

[See a video here](https://vimeo.com/54473855).

This manifests in both gazebo_1.3 and default as of this writing.

values.title: dae and stl lighting

content.raw:
The lighting for colored and textured collada models is pretty bad and causes models to be either lit to 100% or just with ambient light - the amount of actual shading is very minimal. The strength of the lighting is also independent of the distance to the object and the lighting looks a bit like all the normals would point in one direction even though all the normals are correct when viewed in Meshlab. Textures aren't affected by lighting at all.

STL models do get proper shading for the most part but a lot of aliasing and what seems to be z-buffer fighting is caused by shadows (?) or shading on the model.

See attached pictures and this video for examples using the google warehouse gator: http://youtu.be/ICuwtodhDHk

values.title: gztopic echo blocks gazebo

content.raw:
Echoing a Gazebo topic with high bandwidth has a huge effect on Gazebo's update rate - the physics updates might still be fine actually but user input that interacts with objects and world visualization updates take a long time. 

E.g. when running gztopic echo /gazebo/default/physics/contacts with the drc robot standing it starts to lag a lot. The user interface and also moving inside the world is still smooth most of the time but e.g. adding a box to the world, moving and dropping an object takes a long time to update.

values.title: Allow interaction between kinematic and dynamic objects

content.raw:
As discussed on the gazebo mailing list ( http://kforge.ros.org/pipermail/gazebo-list/2012-November/004337.html ) it would be nice to have kinematic objects be able to interact with dynamic objects. Right now physics needs to be turned off for the whole world while animating joints with disabled dynamics.

One example use-case would be to allow a robot arm to be controlled kinematically but still collide with and move dynamic objects in the scene.
Another use-case would be some moving obstacle that pushes dynamic objects away but doesn't get affected by dynamics.
content.html:
As discussed on the gazebo mailing list ( http://kforge.ros.org/pipermail/gazebo-list/2012-November/004337.html ) it would be nice to have kinematic objects be able to interact with dynamic objects. Right now physics needs to be turned off for the whole world while animating joints with disabled dynamics.

One example use-case would be to allow a robot arm to be controlled kinematically but still collide with and move dynamic objects in the scene. Another use-case would be some moving obstacle that pushes dynamic objects away but doesn't get affected by dynamics.

values.title: DEBUG or Debug?

content.raw:
Gazebo checks `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE` against strings: `DEBUG`, `RELEASE`, `PROFILE` to determine build flags.  But most other software libraries we depend on (i.e. bullet, ogre, simbody, etc.) checks against non-all-upper-case strings, i.e. `Debug` or `Release`.

Should we make gazebo check `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE` against strings: `Debug`, `Release` and `Profile` instead?
content.html:
Gazebo checks CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE against strings: DEBUG, RELEASE, PROFILE to determine build flags. But most other software libraries we depend on (i.e. bullet, ogre, simbody, etc.) checks against non-all-upper-case strings, i.e. Debug or Release.

Should we make gazebo check CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE against strings: Debug, Release and Profile instead?

values.title: allow for command-line arguments to system plugins

content.raw:
We propose the addition of a `--server-plugin-args` or `-a` command line argument used for passing strings options to a server system plugin.  For example:

~~~
gazebo -s libsystemplugin.so my.world --server-plugin-args "__name:=rosnode_name"
~~~

or equivalently
~~~
gazebo -s libsystemplugin.so my.world -a "__name:=rosnode_name"
~~~

such that the use can explicitly specify command line inputs into a server plugin.

One use case is in a ros launched gazebo node, where if one of the system plugin is ros-based, it might need `argc` and `argv` for its `ros::init(argc, argv, ...)` call.

Currently, gazebo passes all command line arguments into `Server::ParseArgs(argc, argv)`, where the are stored in `Server::systemPluginsArgc` and `Server::systemPluginsArgv`, to be consumed by `Server::LoadImpl(...)` in its call to `gazebo.cc`'s `gazebo::load(Server::systemPluginsArgc, Server::systemPluginsArgv)`.

Also, currently, gazebo ignores anything it does not recognize in its command line inputs.  For example, if user starts gazebo with:
~~~
gazebo -s libsystemplugin.so -u my.world __name:=rosnode_name
~~~
gazebo will happily ignore the last argument.  But this is not a desirable behavior, as ideally we want gazebo to error out with unrecognized command line arguments.
content.html:
We propose the addition of a --server-plugin-args or -a command line argument used for passing strings options to a server system plugin. For example:

gazebo -s libsystemplugin.so my.world --server-plugin-args "__name:=rosnode_name"

or equivalently

gazebo -s libsystemplugin.so my.world -a "__name:=rosnode_name"

such that the use can explicitly specify command line inputs into a server plugin.

One use case is in a ros launched gazebo node, where if one of the system plugin is ros-based, it might need argc and argv for its ros::init(argc, argv, ...) call.

Currently, gazebo passes all command line arguments into Server::ParseArgs(argc, argv), where the are stored in Server::systemPluginsArgc and Server::systemPluginsArgv, to be consumed by Server::LoadImpl(...) in its call to gazebo.cc's gazebo::load(Server::systemPluginsArgc, Server::systemPluginsArgv).

Also, currently, gazebo ignores anything it does not recognize in its command line inputs. For example, if user starts gazebo with:

gazebo -s libsystemplugin.so -u my.world __name:=rosnode_name

gazebo will happily ignore the last argument. But this is not a desirable behavior, as ideally we want gazebo to error out with unrecognized command line arguments.

values.title: allow user to set startup sim-time when starting gazebo paused

content.raw: By default, sim time is 0 when starting gazebo paused, when we should probably set it to something closer to wall time, given sim time of 0 might have special meanings (e.g. ros treats sim time of 0 differently).

values.title: Save world from GUI with options

content.raw: When you save a world in the GUI, it just grabs everything you've put in and inputs the SDF code for all lights, objects, etc.  It would be nice to have a menu pop up when saving that lets you individually select or deselect components to save into the world, so someone can quickly edit permanent features like walls and lights, and spawn in items like robots separately.

values.title: Allow SDF Conversion across different elements

content.raw:
For example, [sdf conversion from sdf 1.0 to sdf 1.2](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c8974309a98df2fe9bb6c7cdb9f5c74866caf535/gazebo/sdf/1.2/1_0.convert?at=default) allows remap within an element.  To expand conversion to inter-element nodes, e.g.
~~~
<world>
  <physics>
    <update_rate>1</update_rate>
  </physics>
</world>
~~~
to
~~~
<world>
  <real_time_update_rate>1</real_time_update_rate>
  <physics>
  </physics>
</world>
~~~

might require something like below:
~~~
  <convert name="world">
    <move>
      <from>
        <convert name="physics">
          <src element="update_rate"/>
        </convert>
      </from>
      <to>
        <dst element="real_time_update_rate"/>
      </to>
    </move>
  </convert>
~~~
More examples in [physics_sdf_refactor branch](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/ed00985423b86f4838ae31841a1dcba96c56332c/gazebo/sdf/1.4/1_3.convert?at=physics_sdf_refactor).
content.html:
For example, sdf conversion from sdf 1.0 to sdf 1.2 allows remap within an element. To expand conversion to inter-element nodes, e.g.

<world>
  <physics>
    <update_rate>1</update_rate>
  </physics>
</world>

to

<world>
  <real_time_update_rate>1</real_time_update_rate>
  <physics>
  </physics>
</world>

might require something like below:

  <convert name="world">
    <move>
      <from>
        <convert name="physics">
          <src element="update_rate"/>
        </convert>
      </from>
      <to>
        <dst element="real_time_update_rate"/>
      </to>
    </move>
  </convert>

More examples in physics_sdf_refactor branch.

However, when I delete it the scene does go dark. This seems to be a glitch.

values.title: Don't use ${urdfdom_LDFLAGS} and ${console_bridge_LDFLAGS} in target_link_libraries

content.raw:
Using the LDFLAGS variables in target_link_libraries leads to linker errors such as `cannot find -l/usr/lib/libboost_thread.so` or similar things. The problem occurs when building with ROS groovy installed since in that case, urdfdom and console_bridge can be found and will be enabled. Instead,  ${urdfdom_LIBRARIES} and ${console_bridge_LIBRARIES} should be used.

The problem occurs when building libgazebo_sdf_interface. A patch is attached.
content.html:
Using the LDFLAGS variables in target_link_libraries leads to linker errors such as cannot find -l/usr/lib/libboost_thread.so or similar things. The problem occurs when building with ROS groovy installed since in that case, urdfdom and console_bridge can be found and will be enabled. Instead, ${urdfdom_LIBRARIES} and ${console_bridge_LIBRARIES} should be used.

The problem occurs when building libgazebo_sdf_interface. A patch is attached.

values.title: UI Control Plugin

content.raw: It would be cool if there were a plug-in type that made it easy to write controls for different input devices to manipulate things in Gazebo, like the user camera.

values.title: Read controller/joint values in joint control widget

content.raw: Currently Gazebo's joint control widget always displays default values but doesn't read the controller's/joint's values. It also doesn't keep the values you set when you deselect and select the model again but rather goes back to displaying its default values.
content.html: Currently Gazebo's joint control widget always displays default values but doesn't read the controller's/joint's values. It also doesn't keep the values you set when you deselect and select the model again but rather goes back to displaying its default values.

values.title: Projector disables collision visuals

content.raw:
The projector (used on the PR2) turns off collision visuals. 

Example:

1. Insert a simple shape, and turn on collision visuals.

1. Insert a PR2 and point its projector to hit the simple shape
